title: Intermittent hang in .NET CLI build
body:
The .NET CLI and ProdCon teams have observed occasional hangs in their build process with no obvious explanation. Creating this as a tracking issue.

Known instances with signatures:

## Zombie child of entry-point MSBuild 

dotnet/corefx#31559

Signature from `pstree`: a process in parentheses is a child of the topmost `dotnet exec .../MSBuild.dll`

## JIT hang

dotnet/coreclr#19217

Appears to happen only on Ubuntu 14.04.

Hangs in a test (much deeper process tree), with a thread in ``libclrjit.so`Compiler::fgMorph()``

nodes.body: I lost the first hang that I tried to debug, but observed that the only `dotnet` processes running were MSBuild and its worker nodes, and that there was no hung tool process in the process tree.

What I've observed from the hang on (internal link) https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=1901621&view=logs

> possibly related to dotnet/corefx#27249 or dotnet/corefx#19695.

With the latest patch release, 2.1 should clean-up all child processes shortly after they terminate.
2.1.300 has an issue that `Console.CancelKeyPress` when blocked would prevent reaping of child processes (https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/29699). But probably that event is not used/emitted here.

> I could believe a bug in our event handlers, but is there any way to tell after the fact if, say, we should have received the Exited event already?

The Exited event is emitted after the zombie is cleaned up. So if you are seeing the zombie, the Exited event can't be emitted yet.

Child reaping is done from a native thread: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/89fe18fc44397309b59af62a01d5e6a8a662a2e8/src/Native/Unix/System.Native/pal_signal.c#L84
You can check if there is something blocking this thread. When idle, it should be in the read call: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/89fe18fc44397309b59af62a01d5e6a8a662a2e8/src/Native/Unix/System.Native/pal_signal.c#L100

Child reaping is triggered by the OS sending the SIGCHLD signal. It is interesting to see how the .NET Core process responds to that signal.
To do this, strace the process: `strace -e waitid,waitpid -f -p <pid>`. And then send it SIGCHLD `kill -CHLD <pid>`. The strace should show a `waitid` call that .NET Core uses to figure out what children terminated.
